Joint note: focuses on seagrass biodiversity, methods irrelevant to ours [**annie**] Nice review paper, different system, but looks at trophic interactions, regional differences and ecosystem processes so might be useful for intro or discussion [**ingrid**]
role of diversity on pelagic ecosystem functioning [**edgar**]
could be relevant if we find that species richness is important [**annie**]
studies fisheries collapse and recovery in relation with species richness at the LME level [**edgar**] I concur with edgar [**ingrid**]
claims longer time series are not more prone to collapse, if we are using catch data, the original papers methods could be useful [**annie**]
deals with invertebrate fisheries and only studies explotation trends [**edgar**], agree with edgar [**annie**]

introduce a revised method for assessing fisheries status that includes: smoothing the data iteratively to account for stochasticity, and declaring fisheries developing if within a certain number of years after the peak in smoothed catch. also suggest revising the thresholds for the classifications of fishery status based on stock-assessment reference points [**vanessa**]; uses RAM database but only to apply it to an alternative method to assess fisheries status: iteratively smoothing catch series; I like this method as it account for sources of stochasticity  [**edgar**].
uses mean trophic level (MTL) as a biodiversity indicator of shifts in fisheries. Might be useful to compare our results to this metric in the discussion [**ingrid**]
Reassesses % fisheries over exploited/ collapsed with catch and biomass data (stock assessments). [**ingrid**]
authors say that the ocean food provision index and MSY cannot be estimated from simple functions of current catch and maximum catch [**annie**]
introduces a new length-based reference point [**edgar**] I concur with edgar  [**ingrid**]
compared Bmsy based reference points to IUCN status to see if conservation/fisheries scientist are consistent with species status [**annie**] I concur with annie  [**ingrid**]
suggests balanced harvesting techniques (compared to selective) to make fisheries more sustainable [**ingrid**]

Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Joint note: only states that fisheries are important for developing countries' food security, could be used for the intro section: fisheries are important [**edgar**], provides evidence for why 'fisheries are important' part of our message box, but I imagine there are more comprehensive reviews that could serve this purpose for our introduction [**annie**]
trade-off between conservation and exploitation of the California Current Bottom-Trawl fishery, potentially useful dataset: NOAA's annual commercial landings by group DB [**edgar**]
opinion piece on using FAO catch data [**ingrid**]
assesses whether the convention on biological diversity (CBD) targets reduce the rate of biodiversity loss in marine fisheries.  [**ingrid**]
uses RAM database to test ecological theories pertaining to population and ecosystem dynamics (e.g. density dependence, recruitment, trophic cascades) [**annie**]

uses a mixed effect model, finds that management (specifically catch shares) improve (less variation in catch around quota targets) but there was no observed effect on biomass. They also found strong regional effects [**annie**]
different management strategies have different effects on fisheries, thus it is a covariate we should consider [**edgar**] I concur with edgar [**ingrid**]

Journal: Reviews in fish biology and fisheries

Joint note: overfished stocks are resilient and can recover quickly, but prolonged overexploitation of collapsed stocks will delay recovery and decrease its likelihood. [**annie**] Factors contributing to the recovery of fisheries, doesn't include many env. or socioeconomic factors.[**ingrid**]

Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Joint note: uses RAM DB, we used a similar Method, they use two definitions of collapse: one for assessment data and one landings data, should we do the same? [**edgar**]
computes time series of growndfish stocks using publicly available trawl survey data [**annie**] I concur with annie  [**ingrid**]
introduces and explains the RAM DB [**edgar**]

Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Joint note: using global data on catch , ex-vessel price (which measures of the economic value of a fishery), and life history characteristics to examine whether higher trophic level organisms are more valuable. Linear regression of trophic level against log transformed price index and revenue index. They also looked at the chronology of global fishery development by trophic level, revenue index, mean annual catch, price index, geometric mean of depth range, and length.a chronology of global development patterns. Maybe a somewhat similar approach to ours? [**vanessa**]. found no statistically significant relationship between economic value and fishery trophic level, could be useful in choosing explanatory variables, interesting because they look at economic drivers of harvest [**annie**]

Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Joint note: uses RAM database and finds that taxonomic order and body size are explanatory variables for the ratio of spawning biomass at maximum sustainable yield to average unfished spawning biomass (SBmsy/SB0) [**edgar**]. I concur with edgar [**ingrid**]

Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Joint note: abundance and productivity (net population increase) are related in some stocks and unrelated in others. Irregular changes in productivity are common, and management plans should reflect the irregular changes in productivity. Uses a surplus production model [**annie**]

fisheries-status trends analysed from a regional and community perspective focusing on different management strategies in diffferent regions [**edgar**], agree with edgar, this is one of the papers we all read [**annie**]

very similar to our envisioned synthesis approach. Hard to find the exact methodology, which turns out to be embedded in Figure legends. So refer to figures for detailed method descriptions [**vanessa**]; only states that fisheries' low management capacity explains the decline of fisheries in developing countries [**edgar**].
